a mental disorder is not equivalent to a need for treatment. Need for
treatment is a complex clinical decision that takes into consideration
symptom severity, symptom salience (e.g., the presence of suicidal ide-
ation), the patient’s distress (mental pain) associated with the symp-
tom(s), disability related to the patient’s symptoms, risks and benefits
of available treatments, and other factors (e.g., psychiatric symptoms
complicating other illness). Clinicians may thus encounter individuals
whose symptoms do not meet full criteria for a mental disorder but
who demonstrate a clear need for treatment or care. The fact that some
individuals do not show all symptoms indicative of a diagnosis should
not be used to justify limiting their access to appropriate care.

mental disorders have included the following types of evidence: ante-

and environmental exposure), concurrent validators (similar neural
